ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Linear algebra and basic proofs
Basics of linear algebra. Also learned some good mathematical reasoning and basic proof skills
I learned how to become a calculator.

I practiced linear algebra by hand. The most useful thing we did was the end of the extra credit assignment, a compression problem; it was the only application of linear algebra in a class titled Linear Algebra with Applications. Please rename the course to Linear Algebra with Application.

The basics of linear algebra, with limited to no applications. The only application came on the final problem of the extra credit problem set that was due during reading period. This required skills not learned within the course (coding). Most of the insights came from the problem sets, and almost all skills were surrounding the ability to do linear algebra by hand, with almost no use of computing power.
I learned a lot of topics in computational linear algebra such as matrix projections, orthogonality, inverses, eigenvalues/vectors, and more.
I feel that I successfully learned every linear algebra concept discussed in the course to a very comfortable level.
A working knowledge of linear algebra and how to deal with matrix problems.
linear algebra concepts but not a super great conceptual understanding
Gaussian elimination through singular value decomposition...basically follows Gilbert Strangs MIT course
I learned what is linear algebra, how to use matrices to solve different type equations
I got a clearer understanding of linear algebra while developing problem solving skills.
Linear Algebra. Frankly, I've learnt linear algebra in high school so this is a bit of repetition for me, although I did learn some new stuff.
A bunch of linear algebra stuff I'm probably never gonna use much of again

I learned the basics of linear algebra from matrix manipulation and its applications to vector spaces to eigen-things. I also learned how to become a human calculator doing endless rational multiplication and addition on some of the later psets.

Your typical intro-level LinAlg repertoire -- after the basics like matrix multiplication, elementary row operations, Gauss-Jordan etc., the fun stuff included vector space and subspace, column space and null space of a matrix, representing linear transformations using matrices, diagonalization, eigen-stuff, and SVD!
I learned about the fundamentals and applications of linear algebra.
Learned concepts and how to solve practical linear algebra problems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: prelectures are slightly helpful but I hated that one of the instructors used powerpoint to show math... Midterm practice problems are helpful. Poor explanations of intuition..

Strengths: Good support system with frequent office hours with profs/TAs/peer tutors. Good instructor. Class lectures were helpful with problem sets. Weaknesses: Videos and lectures each week were a significant time commitment. I did not like that the instructor who did the pre-recorded videos rotated from week to week, especially because the teaching with the other two instructors (not Taylor) was often very unclear and lacking in examples. Exam prep resources were scarce and not helpful

course was organized well up until the material for the 3rd midterm, which was very condensed with respect to its weight and significance. In addition, the applications to differential equations seemed outside of the scope of the course and was material more reminiscent of a course in differential equations, while the course skipped over some crucial concepts in linear algebra, such as the Jordan canonical form. Also glossed over rowspace and left nullspace, which were referred to many times implicitly but not by name, which would have improved clarity of lecture. In addition, some assignments, especially the later problem sets and 3rd midterm, felt more like tests of mental computational/arithmetic ability using complicated fractions and radicals than assessments/exercises of conceptual understanding.

There were many problems with this class. The prerecorded videos varied in quality and content, and the live classes covered the same material, so the videos became unnecessary. 
The problem sets were significantly more difficult than anything covered in class (which on its own is fine), but also covered a significant amount of material never discussed in class. The problem sets also focused on computation over understanding theory, so 70% of the work on the psets was calculating a matrix multiplication, inverse, or eigenvalues/eigenvectors by hand rather than demonstrating knowledge of a new concept. As a result they became incredibly tedious. 
The exams also focused on computation, where an algebra mistake on a timed exam could cost the majority of the points on a problem despite the correct method being used.

I am struggling to think of a strength for this course. The format of the course was fundamentally flawed; while it was conceived and marketed as a flipped classroom, the professors extensively reviewed the content from the videos during the live zoom sessions. The necessity of the review was due to the videos' poor quality and the professors lack of communication. It was often made apparent during the live sessions that the separate professors did not watch each other's videos. Thus, we could not ask questions on the videos, causing further confusion.

There were little to no strengths of the course, with the only few coming from a wide range of content practiced on problem sets. There was a clear lack of understanding and clarity in almost all of the concepts in the course by the three professors. To make up for this, the course format was a hybrid flipped classroom, if you could call it that. The content was "taught" in recorded videos before each live class period, but was often so vague in instruction that the entire live class would need to be spent re-teaching the material. There was a clear lack of communication and preparedness by the three professors, who seemed to only be able to reiterate the concepts and proofs from the textbook. The content is difficult, and needs to be properly and efficiently taught, neither of which is true for this course. There also is way too much of an emphasis on theory and proofs, especially considering there is an identical class dedicated to this material with proofs. This class is supposed to be "with applications" but over the entire the semester, 1 application was explained, in the final lecture of the course. I continually asked my during this course "Has anyone even though about how the students are supposed to do this?" For example, on an exam, we were instructed to point our cameras at our hands, while only offering the exam through a PDF we had to view on the same device. For students with laptops, this clearly does not make sense and was not thought through whatsoever. Further, on problem sets, we were repeatedly asked to perform basic computation by hand, over and over throughout the semester, spending literally hours repeating the same process that we learned in the first few weeks of the course that can be easily and expediently calculated using a calculator or online software. Also the professors, despite repeated and varied pleas by a number of students, refused to publish solutions to any problem sets or exams. For the first exam, there were no practice problems published with a few days leading up to the exam. When pressed on the issue, the problems were finally uploaded with the comment in the announcement on canvas "under files->midterm 1 practice: The file is NOT meant to represent the exam, its content, or level of difficulty in any way . . ." What is the purpose of posting these problems which are practice for the exam if they do not represent the content on the exam? Additionally, there were no solutions posted to these problems for the first midterm, and they were posted for the second midterm they were riddled with computational errors in the Professor's handwritten document. The exams were also graded with little to no clarity, with an emphasis on the depth of explanation on computational math problems, regardless of correct answers, points were taken off repeatedly if an unexplained level of explanation was not met. When asked, professor McAdam only had apologies for the lack of clarity instead of an explanation for the removal of points.

The teaching of material was generally not very good. I feel that a lot of steps were taken by professors that leaped from one element to another, not truly clarifying the content. Also, dealing with proofs was never really taught in class but thrown at us in the problem sets. It would be very helpful if solving proof based problems were taught in class before presenting such problems on problem sets.

The dual lecture/seminar format of the course was very helpful for me as it allowed me to learn the material primarily in the pre-recorded lectures before reviewing that material (along with practice problems and additional instruction) in the seminar class times. Unfortunately, this course was taught by three professors, two of whom were not nearly as good at explaining the material, who alternated in the creation of the pre-recorded lectures. Thus, depending on the week, my understanding of the concepts going into my seminar section ranged considerably. Fortunately, my primary professor for the course (the one who always held my seminar section) was the most competent in portraying the course's material, which allowed my understanding to catch up.
The lectures and overall course were very well organized. The course could perhaps be improved by offering more detailed solutions to the study guides to help with preparation for exams.

the class was very organised but the 3 different professors teaching on rotation was very very annoying because they all have different teaching styles and notations and it was difficult to understand and each class had an hour worth of videos we had to watch. Parts were also unnecessarily tedious the questions themselves were not even hard it just was very tedious to calculate to the point where the profs just let us use wolfram alpha to do the basic calculations
Some of the profs arent very good and the course feels really disorganized, but Prof McAdam was great and felt like I learned a lot

Strengths: good peer tutors and Taylor is awesome 
Weakness: class is somewhat unorganized as the three instructors have different teaching methods when watching recorded lectures.
I think the pre-recorded lectures were very helpful in terms of understanding the material in our own time.
I wish the profs making the pre-recorded videos don't rotate.

Strengths: So many office hours, help sessions, etc. 

Weaknesses: Lectures were not recorded and lecture notes were only posted occasionally - it doesn't take all that much effort to keep those resources available for our learning. The breakout rooms were so so hard to participate in during the end of the semester. The course was originally meant to not take the full live class time since we had videos to watch beforehand; this almost never happened, and we went to time or sometimes over most days. The videos before lecture should be scrapped and each professor just teach their class like normal.

The strengths of this course were Taylor McAdam's teaching. She was the only reason I really enjoyed this class, and I felt bad for any students who took the other sections. The problem sets were generally pretty doable, and there are a TON of help hours in this class. You will never feel like you're struggling alone.

Maybe spend less time and energy on going over the more mechanical computations and make more effort in covering and conveying the intuitions and connections between the algebraic expressions and geometric interpretations

Better organization is definitely needed in this course. I loved having Taylor for sections, but the recorded lecture component was taught by all 3 professors. The inconsistencies in their teaching were really frustrating. Another huge weakness was the disparity in exam difficulty and problem sets, the problem sets being much more difficult. Wouldve also appreciated problem set solutions being posted after theyre due.

Weakness: The problem sets were mostly busywork. Please change this! It does not contribute to anyone's learning to be grinding out horrendous numbers. It would be a lot more beneficial to use numbers so that we can practice the concepts and methods. Computers will be used to do the actual number crunching. Furthermore, although we tried to do a flipped classroom, the recorded lectures were lacking. Not only were they not good at teaching the material, they actually made it more confusing. One would be better off saving time and not watching the recorded lectures because they had a negative effect on learning. The course would also be better off if solutions to homework, practice exams, and exams were provided.

Strengths: Professor McAdam was extremely approachable and good at explaining concepts/answering questions.

Taylor was a stellar professor and her pre-lecture videos were great, but when one of the other professors made the pre-lecture videos, I struggled to learn the material. It would have been much better if those videos were written out in real-time instead of just reading off of a prewritten slide, which is not conducive to learning or note-taking. Also, it would have been better if the answer keys for homework and exams were posted afterwards.

Linear algebra is a difficult subject. To improve: please follow the steps of Taylor McAdam and WRITE down the lectures, explaining the theorems/practice problems as you go. Also, please use better handwriting. Some instructors during the recorded lectures were difficult to follow due to preschool handwriting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Record the seminar

Canvas organization (of videos) was occasionally confusing. However, TA/prof/peer tutor Zoom support system was well scheduled and very helpful. I also liked the live lecture format, with whole class reviews from Taylor first and then breakout rooms for practice problems.
This class did not benefit from being online. Classes were not recorded, and thus all the benefits of being remote were lost.
I like the idea of recorded lectures, but the execution by the 3 professors was incredibly poor.

The entire structure attempted in this course did not work. The "flipped" classroom failed, as the recorded videos were not clear enough to suffice as content, so the in class "practice sessions" ended up just be repeated teaching of the same material, with a few example problems, which were more or less useless as they had little correlation with exams, and were too simple to be helpful on problem sets. The content elements of this class were effectively good for a few notes, and an idea of what we needed to learn on our own for the problem sets. Further, the decision to make the exams one note sheet but not open notes, in a course that is entirely computation based, does not make any sense.

The double opportunity to learn the material for each class was definitely a plus. Additionally, there were many opportunities for office hours and discussion sections which seemed as though they could be helpful (though my schedule conflicted with most of the times these occurred). As aforementioned, the only detractor to this course's format was me having to view the pre-recorded lectures of less able professors.
The video lectures were of great quality. Overall the class did very well with adapting to COVID restrictions.
The different teaching styles was actually terrible in a nonCovid semester, it should be improved with only 1 professor.

Succeed: Record lectures
Can improve: provide answers for problem sets and exams.
The pre-recorded lectures were recorded by three different instructors which sometimes caused differences in some methods or ways of explaining questions.

The video lectures before live lecture was not a good move. No one's going to watch double lecture like that, it's not an efficient use of time, especially when the live portion was advertised as being shorter and never was.
Recorded lectures in addition to live lectures felt like overkill for this class. Definitely one or the other would've been better.
The lectures were great, but some of the pre-lecture videos could have been better made.

I would have preferred to get rid of the recorded lectures and have the whole lecture be virtual live, in which the live lectures are then recorded for viewing as need be. The live review sessions were very repetitive, and I learned a lot more from them. Additionally, they were as long as the actual class--1.5 hours instead of just 45 minutes, so we basically had to watch extra recorded lectures that weren't even necessary.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not really
Not for fun, but if you need to know linear algebra, yes. I would definitely recommend taking it with Taylor.

This course spends a relatively small amount of time explaining useful concepts and how they are calculated, and then spends the majority of the time forcing students to calculate things that could easily be done using an online calculator.
No, but it is a requirement. It seems to be a prevalent issue.

No, if these professors (McAdam, Edwards, and Landa) are teaching again, the course is an aggravating experience. Talking to other students who have taken this in the past, this seems to be a repeated problem for this course. The content is difficult, but surely not the most complex when compared to other math courses, and the math department needs to find some teachers adequately prepared to teach the content in an efficient manner.
No, not unless it is a requirement for you. The material could be interesting if presented well, but this class was not taught well.

I would probably recommend this course, though it definitely depends on the student and their capability to take the reigns on their math education. I believe that this course provides a strong likelihood that your professor or lectures alone will not give you the understanding of the material needed to succeed in the course. That being said, the material was fun and interesting and I really enjoyed learning this branch of math. I am very thankful that I took the course even if it was simply a requirement for my major.
Yes. It was well organized and will be useful background for future courses.
you kind of need to take it for many majors so yes. Definitely take over 225 it is a fine gclass mot amazing you just kind of need to get through the class
It is difficult but good
Yes, only if it is required and if you like math. The materials arent too hard to grasp afterward.
I would recommend this course for any student interested in math with no background in linear algebra.
Yes, if you want to learn linear algebra and dislike proofs.

Eh. If you think Linear will be useful to you, sure. It's interesting but quickly becomes complicated and proofy. You also spend the semester doing computations by hand that take forever and is pretty much exclusively done on a computer outside of this setting, so that's a little infuriating sometimes

I would recommend this course to any student interested in linear algebra, but only if Taylor McAdam is teaching. Linear algebra can seem confusing with a professor that doesn't provide the right intuition, but Taylor was always very careful in making sure even the most complex ideas got across to everyone. Definitely prepare to do some mental math with frequent square roots and fractions on the problem sets.
Not unless its for a major requirement
No really. It is a lot of busy work and rote algebra. I think that taking MATH 225, although more work, would be a lot more interesting and fulfilling.
I would recommend it if linear algebra is required or very helpful for your intended major. It's a good introduction to practical linear algebra.
If you have a passion for math, take this course. If you are meeting a requirement and must decide between this course and Math 225, this course is easier and less theoretical with less proofs.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination recorded video lectures and live virtual lectures/practice problems
Pre-recorded videos, then discussed in live unrecorded classes
Recorded lectures, live virtual lectures.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture.
recorded lectures followed by live virtual seminars
The primary learning mode of the course was a set of pre-recorded lectures, although there was also a discussion/seminar class meeting for each class time.
Recorded lectures and in-person lectures.
Class time was office hours
Both recorded lectures and live lectures
Recorded lectures, class reviews and discussions, working with friends on problem sets
There were recorded lectures every week and a live virtual lecture/ discussion section following the topics covered to review, clarify and practice the content.
Combined with recorded lecture.

There were recorded video lectures meant to be watched before the live lecture, but I quickly stopped watching them bc it cycled professors and I could really only understand the teaching of one of the three professors for the class, so I reserved all my learning for her live review
recorded lectures and live virtual classes
Recorded lecture + live virtual lecture
flipped classroom: recorded lectures to watch before the zoom live sessions where the instructor reviews the stuff and the class goes through practice problems together
Live virtual lecture, with recorded pre-lecture videos.
The main lectures were recorded, but the individual instructors held their own discussion/review session.
